title: Theoretical integration of the affect heuristic and implicit attitudes: implications for implicit social cognition, risk perception and acceptability
abstractText:
The first aim of this project is to examine implicit and explicit attitudes towards nuclear power and climate change, and the relationship between these attitudes and perceived risk and public acceptance of these issues.

This research is the first to examine implicit social cognition in relation to both of these concerns. A second aim is to fill a gap in the literature by testing the theoretical integration of implicit attitudes with the affect heuristic. Demonstrating that implicit attitudes and the affect heuristic may be different measures of the same psychological processes is important because:

  1. it would suggest that affect is a central component of implicit attitudes
  2. the two separate strands of research concerning implicit attitudes and the affect heuristic need to re-evaluate their theories and findings in relation to each other.

It is crucial to understand how these constructs relate to each other in order to fully-understand the nature of attitudes towards such societal concerns and create adequate risk communications about these issues.

Two large experiments will be conducted using different methods from the affect heuristic and implicit attitude literatures. Each will provide new knowledge about implicit social cognition, the affect heuristic and risk perception.
